Authors: Lei Wang, Wei-Min Zhang, Liang-Hu Qu
Title:
Polycephalomyces lianzhouensis sp. nov., a new species
co-occur with Ophiocordyceps crinalis
Keywords:
community structure, Cordyceps, ITS, molecular
phylogeny
Abstract:
Two species of Cordyceps s.l., separately or
simultaneously parasitizing a lepidopteran host, collected from
Dadongshan Nature Reserve of Guangdong Province, southern China, are
described and illustrated. They are Cordyceps lianzhouensis, a new
species, and Ophiocordyceps crinalis. Molecular analysis of ITS data
showed these two species to be phylogenetically distant; consistent with
the obvious differences in their morphology. An isolate from the
sclerotium of a collection on which the two species were found is shown
to be the anamorph of C. lianzhouensis. Two distinct DNA fragments,
which accorded with the ITS regions of C. lianzhouensis and O. crinalis,
were amplified from the sclerotium of a collection on which stromata of
only C. lianzhouensis had developed. The community structure of nineteen
sclerotia from nine Corydceps specimens were analyzed by RT-PCR or clone
libraries. It was confirmed that the two Cordyceps s.l. fungi exist on
the same hosts, in different proportions inside different parts of the
host and different specimens. The frequency of synparasitism in
Cordyceps s.l. is probably not high, but we are, nonetheless reminded to
pay greater attention to the possibility of synparasitism in our future
research into the phylogeny, taxonomy, isolation and identification of
Cordyceps s.l. anamorph. We discuss the relationships between Cordyceps
species s.l. and their hosts, and the phylogenetic and evolutionary
relationships between these two species and their allies. Specimens
examined have been deposited in the Fungal Herbarium of Guangdong
Institute of Microbiology (GDGM).
